body: Not true. When companies come out and say they're going to miss guidance/pre announce earnings (AAPL, QRVO, SWKS, NXP to name a few), it's clearly a very real shock to the economy. Once the quarter itself ends on 3/31 we will see another much bigger wave of preannouncements.

author: CapitalC5
body:
I don't think 5G will have a big impact on these companies. There will probably also be a lot of problems after the launch, so I would prefer ATT here.

If you wanna buy stock that benefit more from 5G, think further. Maybe the companies that make the network (Skyworks, Qorvo, etc) or an industry like gaming

author: Vacaythrowaway123
body:
I mean as you found out, bonds have a floor that equities don't. It isn't so much that bonds are trading at $50 now because presumably they bought them at $100 but the average recovery value is $50. Equity can and will go to $0 so you don't have that floor. The other thing is the S&P 500 has a decent amount of junk in it, pun intended. IQV, IRM, DVN, APA, M, QRVO. 

Perhaps the problem with indexing but if you want to trade this strategy, probably better off doing it versus strong balance sheets but even then, equities on the whole are likely to underperform credit on the whole given they are riskier. Where you really see this show up is the IWM (small cap) performance vs SPY or large cap indices. 

The other thing is that there is likely some Fed put in HY. They ain't buying HY yet but they'll buy HY before they buy stocks. Look at the index trading at a NAV premium. If things hit the fan, they'll end up supporting the credit while equity likely goes to 0.

author: mrpoopistan
body:
There's an argument that right now the market isn't unduly fond of companies with more debt and less cash.

There are definitely folks who are preparing to ride the outbreak out for 18 months, and that's suggested in the response to certain companies and their debt and cash levels.

Looking through that filter . . . yeah, they're pretty different. Of the two, WDC is by far the more likely to die a horrible death due to rona.

FTR, I love companies with that sort of profile. I was into Altria, for example, heavy when the threat of mega lawsuits was there. Generally, if you have a proven market and major headwinds, I like you because headwinds aren't forever.

YMMV, obviously.

author: pet_wolverine
body:
Yeah I'd buy more.  I'd move to things a bit more stable than you've got.  No need for emerging market funds in my opinion when developed markets HAVE given 25% annual returns and are currently probably undervalued.

I've been buying blue chips.  Yesterday was BA, WDC, DIS.  I've got a few smaller companies mixed in, but those are limited positions.  UBER, OLED, a few like that.  Aside from the three big names I bought yesterday, I've got a lot of S&P500 stocks at/near the top of my portfolio, and I've been adding to those positions over the past week.

author: swampthing41

author: mrpoopistan
body:
Thx.

I've been birddogging the shorts and pretty much betting against them the last two weeks. Especially on otherwise good businesses.

Just trying to figure out exactly how committed to buy-and-hold I want to be.

FTR, I think we're mostly facing a V-shaped recovery, but I have certain western economies struggling to bounce back. I've mostly focused on companies with greater exposure in their supply chains to Asia. For example, I thought the beating Western Digital took was completely undeserved, and that bet is paying off handsomely.

As long as the U.S. doesn't trigger a debt crisis, I'm fairly optimistic.

author: BroskiMcDoogleheimer
body:
I bought my first option and am still wondering what to do with it. It's WDC Put 49 expiring tomorrow 3/13.

1) If I sell to close the contract I make $750 (or $559 profit after subtracting $191 contract cost)

2) Or I can exercise it and make $989 ($49-$39.11*100) or $798 profit after subtracting the $191 contract cost

So in this scenario exercising yields more profit - $798 vs $559. It's actually quite a big difference. So why do people always sell to close? I must be missing something.

author: ferociousturtle
body:
EQX-- very good management team. It's gotten hammered with the rest of gold, and is at a very good entry point right now.

STX-- it'll benefit from the exponential growth of data over the next decade, and has a better balance sheet than WDC. MU is approaching an attractive price point with the same bull thesis (data growth).

NUE-- well run US steel company, reasonable balance sheet, great long-term track record for management, dividends, etc. It's cyclical, and we may have a ways to go before the bottom, but we're probably closer to the bottom of its cycle than we are to the top.

HCC-- also in steel, it's a metallurgical coal company, which means it's much hated. Been following it for a while. The management seems solid, and it's at a deep discount.

I'm also looking at STMP and BKNG.

author: AbbaFuckingZabba
body:

So far bought WDC, STX, MMM, WFC, BA.    


Watching AVGO, QCOM, JPM, DOW
